<p><strong>The global life insurance industry </strong>has seen significant changes over the past decade. Developing economies—predominantly emerging markets in Asia that were formerly small contributors—have become global growth drivers and now account for more than half of global premium growth (Exhibit 1) and 84 percent of individual annuities growth (Exhibit 2). The availability of data has skyrocketed, and insurers have made progress in advanced analytics and artificial intelligence. Digital and mobile advances have raised the bar on transparency and service quality: customers can now file claims and access agents, insurance quotes, and policy information with a few taps on a screen.</p>
<p>The past decade has also introduced new challenges. Life insurers have not benefitted from the bull market (Exhibit 3). Global penetration fell to 3 percent, and premium growth within most developed markets, hovering just below 2 percent per year, struggled to match GDP. Globally depressed interest rates curtailed investment portfolio returns. More recently, the COVID-19 pandemic has depressed global interest rates even lower than those seen in the 2007–08 global financial crisis, leading to disproportional impact on life insurance stock relative to the rest of the market (Exhibit 4).</p>

<h2>Meeting the moment across three key areas</h2>
<p>Several trends show promise for the life insurance industry in the next decade. Customer demand is at an all-time high. Indeed, the COVID-19 pandemic has only reemphasized the need for mortality protection. Public pension replacement rates are declining and healthcare expenditures are rising—trends also accelerated by the COVID-19 crisis. Economic and demographic trends will also offer tailwinds. The global middle class is rapidly expanding, bringing higher incomes, growing financial wealth, and heightened risks to manage. By 2030, all baby boomers will be age 65 or older,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="56bdb2ec-cc08-41b8-9e19-1c42eefd89ef"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="56bdb2ec-cc08-41b8-9e19-1c42eefd89ef" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Older People Projected to Outnumber Children for First Time in U.S. History,” US Census Bureau, March 13, 2018, census.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> and many are expected to outlive their retirement savings.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cf4485bb-b5bc-453e-a9cd-245d0ac8602c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cf4485bb-b5bc-453e-a9cd-245d0ac8602c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Johnny Wood, “Retirees will outlive their savings by a decade,” World Economic Forum, June 13, 2019, weforum.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>We believe the life insurance industry faces a pivotal, dual opportunity: the chance to fulfill growing customer needs while returning to profitability and growth. To achieve these goals, we expect winning life insurance companies to outperform in three areas in the decade ahead:
</p>
<ol>
    <li>personalize every aspect of the customer experience</li>
    <li>develop flexible product solutions suitable for a challenging regulatory and interest-rate environment</li>
    <li>reinvent skills and capabilities</li>
</ol>
<h3>Personalize every aspect of the customer experience</h3>
<p>The influence of digital leaders in other industries has raised the bar in insurance as well. Several areas offer opportunities for personalization that can strengthen customer relationships.</p>
<p><strong><em>A shift to targeted health management.</em></strong> Life insurers have long maintained a focus on mortality protection, but concern over mortality risk has diminished in many markets, which has reduced demand for core products. Despite recent increases in online research for life insurance, spurred by COVID-19, the long-term decline of mortality risk is likely to continue. In the coming decade, insurers will play an increasingly prominent role in the health of their customers as life expectancy increases and health trends change.</p>
<p>By 2030, the number of people aged 60 and older will grow by more than 50 percent, from 900 million in 2015 to 1.4 billion.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="48b14010-fcd7-424d-8c30-76fbb0ae9bfd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="48b14010-fcd7-424d-8c30-76fbb0ae9bfd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>World Population Ageing 2015: Highlights,</em> United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division, 2015, un.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Further, noncommunicable diseases—those more closely linked to lifestyle and behavior, such as diabetes, heart disease, and lung cancer—will account for 71 percent of all annual deaths globally and represent an increasing proportion of mortality risk.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="28962f3a-93a5-4959-b218-98eab96c26fc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="28962f3a-93a5-4959-b218-98eab96c26fc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Noncommunicable diseases,” World Health Organization, June 1, 2018, who.int.</span></span></span></a></span> We believe these factors will motivate life and annuities manufacturers to engage customers in the shared-value economics of healthy living to increase policyholder longevity.</p>
<p>Technology will play an important part in this transition. The proliferation of data and connected devices, particularly wearables, will continue to make it easier for life insurance companies to play an active role in shaping customer health—to everyone’s benefit. Armed with this information, life insurance companies can provide well-timed, personalized reminders or notifications around diet, disease management, doctor appointments, local health resources, and physical activity. Customers are increasingly willing to share their data in exchange for personalization; <span>today, six in ten consumers globally are comfortable sharing personal details with their insurer in exchange for lower premiums</span>.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="901470d2-b947-44d7-bf5a-9cf760c1bf81"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="901470d2-b947-44d7-bf5a-9cf760c1bf81" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>2020 DXC insurance survey report: The voice of the US customer,</em> dxc.technology.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>This trend has accelerated during the pandemic. Evidence shows that a higher proportion of consumers are willing to share data collected on their watches related to heart rate. In recent months, life insurance companies have relied on more detailed questions and medical records instead of in-person physical exams, which have not been possible with physical distancing.</p>
<p>Shared-value life insurance products, such as Vitality, are in the vanguard. Developed by Discovery Group in South Africa, Vitality pioneered the model of shared-value economics in its product design and pricing, leading to the creation of an engaged wellness ecosystem. Now in 22 markets, the program has seen a 35 percent reduction in mortality among highly engaged members and a 15 percent lower policy-lapse rate.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7fa673ef-9c1a-4339-a771-4005a172cf63"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7fa673ef-9c1a-4339-a771-4005a172cf63" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Integrated Annual Report 2019,</em> Discovery, 2019, discovery.co.za.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, some Japanese life insurance companies are migrating to a “pay as you live” premium schedule with dynamic pricing. For example, customers who exhibit regular healthy behaviors, such as exercising and attending doctor checkups, are rewarded with lower premiums. In the future, we expect to see life insurance transition from the traditional “assess and service” model and shift toward “prescribe and prevent” (Exhibit 5).</p>

<p><strong><em>Continuous underwriting. </em></strong>The evolution toward continuous underwriting, made possible by increased data and device connectivity, will present further opportunity for personalization. Currently, mortality underwriting suffers from two primary data gaps. First, it is constrained to a single moment in time—the initial sale. The only data available at that point are past morbidity and behavioral data on the customer. Second, it fails to account for a customer’s lifestyle changes, which are significantly more controllable.</p>
<p>We envision underwriting evolving in four phases that will increase personalization and customer engagement (Exhibit 6). Currently, insurers focus on automating the underwriting process to improve efficiency gains and reduce inconsistencies (phase 1). Some insurers have advanced to accelerated underwriting, for which applications are submitted digitally (phase 2). Doing so dramatically reduces the need for invasive fluid and paramedical exams and results in near auto-issuance for the majority of policies. Insurers will then graduate to microsegmentation and personalization, for which individualized offers are generated using comprehensive internal and external data sets with enhanced accuracy (phase 3). Finally, winning companies will provide continuous “one-touch” underwriting, with dynamic adjustment based on customer behavior and suggested personalized actions to significantly drive healthier behavior (phase 4). Together, this four-phase evolution flips the underwriting approach on its head, with environment, health, and lifestyle becoming primary inputs and medical data providing only one part of the picture (Exhibit 7).</p>

<p><strong><em>Personalized, omnichannel customer journeys. </em></strong>COVID-19 has accelerated many of the digital and omnichannel elements that were in their early stages. According to our research, more than 90 percent of new business in China historically has been generated through face-to-face interactions. Since the onset of the pandemic, insurance companies have been forced to adopt digital-hybrid solutions by incorporating robo-advisors, video conferencing, and web chats. Moreover, a recent McKinsey survey of European consumers found that 54 percent of customers now prefer direct or digital channels, up from 38 percent before the crisis.</p>
<p>Frontline professionals will continue to play a critical role in reaching customers, so insurers must embrace the integration of physical and digital channels once the crisis subsides. Life insurance companies can direct leads to the channel or agent that best serves each customer’s needs. Further, agents will be armed with advanced analytics on their customer base as well as centrally provided digital leads. Throughout the customer life cycle, life insurance companies will engage in multichannel, personalized customer interactions to promote cross-selling (by identifying the most likely “next product to buy”) and proactively reach out to customers who are likely to lapse. Such interactions have the ability to reduce customer acquisition costs by up to 50 percent, generate 5 to 10 percent of new premiums, and reduce customer churn by up to 30 percent.</p>
<p>Upgrading agent capabilities to more effectively use digital tools will be critical to the pending distribution shift. Indeed, a recent McKinsey survey found that “generating leads” and “building initial client relationships remotely” were the two biggest challenges faced by agents. At the same time, these agents were spending disproportionately more time on customer service and administration than before. Life insurance companies will have to significantly invest in digital infrastructure and place analytics at the core of distribution.</p>
<h3>Develop flexible product solutions suitable for a challenging regulatory and interest-rate environment</h3>
<p>Interest rates have been globally depressed for a decade—and even longer for some economies, such as Germany and Japan. Interest-rate pressure has increased further due to COVID-19, with few signs of abating. At the same time, changing regulations have limited traditional methods of doing business. The most successful life insurers will redouble their focus on innovation and flexibility.</p>
<p><strong><em>A paradigm shift of the guaranteed product. </em></strong>Over the past five to seven years, some countries (such as France, Germany, the Netherlands, and Switzerland) saw new government bonds issued at negative yields. Meanwhile, others (such as the United States and Japan) continue to combat near zero interest rates. Indeed, according to the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority, more than half of European life policies guarantee an investment return to policyholders that exceeds the yield on the local ten-year government bond.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5a234f68-e70d-442f-8119-f3fa695778c2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5a234f68-e70d-442f-8119-f3fa695778c2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>IMF Blog,</em> “European Life Insurers: Unsustainable Business Model,” blog entry by Reinout De Bock, Andrea Maechler, and Nobuyasu Sugimoto,
    May 5, 2015, blogs.imf.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>New capital regulations accompanied the globally depressed rates. For example, the introduction of Solvency II in 2016 in the European Union increased capital requirements for traditional life and annuity products, putting further pressure on profitability. Consumers will continue to seek out guaranteed returns, which means many insurers will face challenges in offering guarantees in a capital-efficient, profitable manner. Collectively, traditional long-term, fixed-rate guaranteed products will undergo a paradigm shift in structure, from being rooted in guaranteed returns to offering upside potential with guaranteed downside protection.
</p>
<p>Several life insurance companies have already begun moving their portfolios toward a wide variety of capital-markets products, specifically hybrids and unit-linked products, that are more capital efficient and perform well in a low-rate environment. From 2015 to 2019, unit-linked premiums rose $76 billion globally, with European life insurance companies accounting for two-thirds of global growth (Exhibit 8). Such products may offer customers upside potential coupled with downside protection (as high as 100 percent). That said, capital preservation is not free; whether in commissions, expense ratios, or yield, customers pay for it.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 8</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20life%20insurance%20reimagining%20the%20industry%20for%20the%20decade%20ahead/svgz_mck_glir_ex8.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Western European insurers account for two-thirds of global growth in unit-linked premiums." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20life%20insurance%20reimagining%20the%20industry%20for%20the%20decade%20ahead/svgz_mck_glir_ex8.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Regardless of interest-rate movement, previous fixed-rate guarantees, coupled with new regulations and customer education around alternatives, will likely keep life insurance companies focused on capital-light products in the decade ahead.</p>
<p><strong><em>Tailor new solutions for different life stages.</em></strong> In the coming decade, the industry will see the emergence of new types of coverage, as well as increasing flexibility in product coverage and payment. Household debt is still more than 100 percent of net disposable income in most OECD countries,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b8b795d-d626-4d7f-98d7-7b2b26b04445"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b8b795d-d626-4d7f-98d7-7b2b26b04445" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Household debt,” Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, 2020, data.oecd.org.</span></span></span></a></span> divorce rates continue to rise, and job insecurity, spurred by technological advancements, can create uncertainty for consumers. Indeed, despite a decade of global economic growth, nearly 50 percent of consumers are somewhat or very concerned about job loss for themselves or <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/mckinsey-2020-global-consumer-sentiment-survey-a-tale-of-two-segments">a member of their household</a>. New products that help allay those concerns, as well as increase coverage and premium flexibility, will likely prove increasingly popular with consumers.</p>
<p>Flexible offerings, which allow the consumer to adjust coverage throughout the life of the policy, have been met with favor in Japan. For example, a leading Japanese insurer offers medical, asset accumulation, and protection against dread disease and mortality wrapped into a single product, enabling the customer to add or reduce coverage as their circumstances change.</p>
<p><strong><em>Value-added services and nonmonetary benefits. </em></strong>Over the next decade, product innovation will likely expand to adjacent services. Life insurance companies, which are competing with not only their peers but also industry alternatives such as pure wealth and asset managers, will increasingly seek to differentiate themselves through value-added services and nonmonetary benefits, particularly as life and health coverage continue to converge.</p>
<p>In Asia and Europe, life insurance companies are already offering administrative support for medical visits,
health management, and telemedicine. Going forward, these companies could also partner with ridesharing companies and hotels to provide transportation to doctor visits or accommodations for loved ones in times of need.</p>
<p>Nonmonetary benefits can also address the risk needs of policyholders. For customers concerned with the cost of living in retirement, life insurance companies in Asia and the United Kingdom are replacing financial payouts with guaranteed placement in senior living communities.</p>
<p>Such services give insurers access to fee-based earnings, an alternative revenue stream that could be rewarded by investors. At the same time, fee-based earnings introduce more complexity vis-<span>à</span>-vis sales and after-sales support. Ultimately, earnings potential will be shaped by not only customer demand but also companies’ abilities to upskill distribution talent and develop unique economic solutions for distributors.</p>
<h3>Reinvent skills and capabilities</h3>
<p>The path to growth in the next decade will require new talent and bolder strategies. Life insurers must respond by capturing more value from existing assets and pursuing targeted M&A.</p>
<p><strong><em>A radically different workforce, underpinned by skills of the future.</em></strong> By 2030, 44 percent of insurance work activities have the potential to be automated (Exhibit 9). Roles that focus on repetitive work and manual processes will cease to exist in their present form, while technology and digitally savvy workers will increase in value. Emotional, interpersonal, and social skills will also become more critical, especially for customer-facing agents who can help consumers address their changing financial and coverage needs. However, these workforce shifts will not eliminate jobs—our research indicates net new jobs will be created due to advances in automation—but instead change the nature of the work. The COVID-19 pandemic has only accelerated such trends.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 9</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20life%20insurance%20reimagining%20the%20industry%20for%20the%20decade%20ahead/svgz_life-insurance-ex9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The automation potential of work activities varies by sector." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/the%20future%20of%20life%20insurance%20reimagining%20the%20industry%20for%20the%20decade%20ahead/svgz_life-insurance-ex9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In the war for digital talent, life insurance companies are at a disadvantage. The financial-services industry trails other sectors in volume of digital and tech talent. In fact, 80 percent of millennials say they have limited knowledge of the insurance industry,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="336d3cc1-3acd-45f5-8ecc-310a0db9a1d3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="336d3cc1-3acd-45f5-8ecc-310a0db9a1d3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Millennial generation attitudes about work and the insurance industry, </em>a joint paper from The Institutes and Griffith Insurance Education
    Foundation, 2012, theinstitutes.org.</span></span></span></a></span> a troubling sign for an industry in which 25 percent of employees believe themselves to be within <a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-in-america-people-and-places-today-and-tomorrow">five to ten years of retirement</a>.  However, COVID-19 and recent social unrest present an opportunity for life insurers to reframe their societal purpose, which may help recruit and retain exceptional talent.</p>
<p>Seventy-five percent of global executives agree that <a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/retraining-and-reskilling-workers-in-the-age-of-automation">upskilling and reskilling employees</a> must account for at least half of their skills gap solution.  Life insurance companies that prioritize those efforts and develop operating models capable of responding to changing demands will distinguish themselves from peers and position themselves at the forefront of “future-proofing” their workforces.</p>
<p><strong><em>Substantial value from in-force and closed blocks. </em></strong>Given global profitability challenges, insurers can increasingly optimize in-force and closed blocks as a source of value creation. Today, the attention given to in-force management is often not commensurate with its potential. Life insurance companies can enhance in-force value creation by executing across four pillars:</p>
<ul>
    <li>commercial effectiveness, including lapse management and cross-selling to policyholders</li>
    <li>financial efficiencies, such as actuarial optimization and reinsurance</li>
    <li>operational efficiencies, such as reduced administrative costs</li>
    <li>transactions, such as partial or full sales of blocks of business</li>
</ul>
<p>Companies can also extract value from closed blocks, which sometimes have unattractive product economics and operational difficulties or are misaligned with a company’s strategy. Yet given their cash flow potential, earnings, and embedded value, closed blocks deserve time, attention, and resources. Some insurers have helped fund investment in a digital transformation or an analytics road map by rationalizing their closed blocks of business.</p>
<p>By collaborating with actuaries and understanding the implications on the cost model, life insurance companies can often lock in savings and have a onetime release of reserves that is typically in the ten-to-one range (this ratio differs by company). In other words, for every $1 million saved in long-term in-force servicing costs on the closed block, there could be a $10 million onetime reserve release. Life insurance companies often use these funds to finance the transition of the closed blocks to a target platform, invest in digital and analytics, and wide-scale productivity transformations. The reserve can also be used in other ways to reduce the ongoing unit costs.</p>
<p>The prevalence of closed-block specialists will also spark increased sales by insurance companies beyond
US and UK markets, where activity has been high. Specialists, whose scale facilitates lower costs per policy, have proven themselves to be effective operators. Moreover, closed-block sales can provide life insurance companies with immediate access to capital, derisked balance sheets, and a reduction in operational costs, such as legacy IT systems. But life insurance companies must remain open to exploring sales, and they can limit the risk of undervaluing their blocks by keeping an eye on the cost base, considering improvements, and structuring partnerships with potential buyers.</p>
<p><strong><em>Precision M&A for expansion and capability building.</em></strong> Global M&A remained steady in the 2010s. The Americas accounted for 49 percent of deal volume by the end of the decade, followed by Europe at 32 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3417cd9b-eaa4-4f52-904f-6be81ece140e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3417cd9b-eaa4-4f52-904f-6be81ece140e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Navigating a course between uncertainty and opportunity: Insurance growth report 2019,</em> Clyde & Co, 2019, clydeco.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Effective M&A—specifically as a vehicle for market expansion, capability building, and divesting noncore businesses—can continue to be a core strategy for successful life insurance companies.</p>
<p>Growth within existing markets will be challenging; life insurance companies can use acquisitions to enter new geographies, adjacencies, and products. Cross-border transactions can provide access to faster-growing developing markets, such as those in Latin America, and emerging markets in Asia. Moreover, the global middle class, projected to include six billion people by 2030,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b8976caa-3dc0-40c9-ba0a-04d25a268f31"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b8976caa-3dc0-40c9-ba0a-04d25a268f31" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Annual disposable income of $3,600 and over; World Population Prospects, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, un.org; <em>Cityscope </em>by McKinsey Global Institute.</span></span></span></a></span> will increasingly depend on robust wealth- and asset-management solutions, particularly in markets such as China, where the industry is evolving rapidly. Several life insurance companies have already expanded into such asset-management adjacencies, which have natural synergies with the industry’s core competencies. Others may find capital-light, fee-based businesses in areas related to other competencies to be more practical. Regardless, given the historically strong correlation between return on equity and price-to-book ratio, such investors reward higher return-on-equity businesses.</p>
<p>Life insurance companies can also rely on acquisitions for tech enablement and capability building. The past decade has witnessed the rise of insurtech, which attracted nearly $4 billion of global venture funding in 2018 alone.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bb1cd4f0-a5a8-4c3c-9a65-a2ecf4e77889"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bb1cd4f0-a5a8-4c3c-9a65-a2ecf4e77889" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Joanna Glasner, “A record $2.5B went to U.S. insurance startup deals last year, and big insurers are in all the way,” Crunchbase, April 4, 2019,
    crunchbase.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Partially fueling the segment’s rise are the increasingly popular internal venture-capital funds launched by life insurance companies themselves. Such funds provide access to leading start-ups and serve as a natural “buy” versus “build” entry point for leading technologies. Insurtechs can also help companies increase their pace of innovation. The recent crisis has depressed valuations for start-ups, providing insurers an opportunity to acquire capabilities more cost effectively. As a result, life insurance companies can acquire their way to the forefront of disruptive innovation. If a full acquisition is not an option, hiring talent from insurtechs and other start-ups with greater digital and analytics capabilities is another possibility.</p>
<p>Finally, “shrink to grow” will likely prove a popular way for life insurance companies to launch their next growth S-curves. Divestitures of business lines or books of business, an increasingly popular trend at the end of the 2010s, can unlock capital to focus on new opportunities.
</p>

id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"The future of life insurance Reimagining the industry for the decade ahead","displayName":"The future of life insurance Reimagining the industry for the decade ahead","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"3fa6f2d7-5cf7-48bb-970e-5c45e9f44a54","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The future of life insurance: Reimagining the industry for the decade ahead"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"The future of life insurance"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Over the past decade, life insurers have struggled with growth and profitability. By focusing on three priorities, insurers can reinvent themselves and reestablish their vital role in customers\u0026rsquo; lives."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"By focusing on three priorities, life insurers can reinvent themselves and reestablish their vital role in customers’ lives."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-09-29T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe global life insurance industry \u003c/strong\u003ehas seen significant changes over the past decade. Developing economies\u0026mdash;predominantly emerging markets in Asia that were formerly small contributors\u0026mdash;have become global growth drivers and now account for more than half of global premium growth (Exhibit 1) and 84 percent of individual annuities growth (Exhibit 2). The availability of data has skyrocketed, and insurers have made progress in advanced analytics and artificial intelligence. Digital and mobile advances have raised the bar on transparency and service quality: customers can now file claims and access agents, insurance quotes, and policy information with a few taps on a screen.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe past decade has also introduced new challenges. Life insurers have not benefitted from the bull market (Exhibit 3). Global penetration fell to 3 percent, and premium growth within most developed markets, hovering just below 2 percent per year, struggled to match GDP. Globally depressed interest rates curtailed investment portfolio returns. More recently, the COVID-19 pandemic has depressed global interest rates even lower than those seen in the 2007\u0026ndash;08 global financial crisis, leading to disproportional impact on life insurance stock relative to the rest of the market (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch2\u003eMeeting the moment across three key areas\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral trends show promise for the life insurance industry in the next decade. Customer demand is at an all-time high. Indeed, the COVID-19 pandemic has only reemphasized the need for mortality protection. Public pension replacement rates are declining and healthcare expenditures are rising\u0026mdash;trends also accelerated by the COVID-19 crisis. Economic and demographic trends will also offer tailwinds. The global middle class is rapidly expanding, bringing higher incomes, growing financial wealth, and heightened risks to manage. By 2030, all baby boomers will be age 65 or older,[[Footnote 1]] and many are expected to outlive their retirement savings.[[Footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe believe the life insurance industry faces a pivotal, dual opportunity: the chance to fulfill growing customer needs while returning to profitability and growth. To achieve these goals, we expect winning life insurance companies to outperform in three areas in the decade ahead:\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003epersonalize every aspect of the customer experience\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003edevelop flexible product solutions suitable for a challenging regulatory and interest-rate environment\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ereinvent skills and capabilities\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePersonalize every aspect of the customer experience\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe influence of digital leaders in other industries has raised the bar in insurance as well. Several areas offer opportunities for personalization that can strengthen customer relationships.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eA shift to targeted health management.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Life insurers have long maintained a focus on mortality protection, but concern over mortality risk has diminished in many markets, which has reduced demand for core products. Despite recent increases in online research for life insurance, spurred by COVID-19, the long-term decline of mortality risk is likely to continue. In the coming decade, insurers will play an increasingly prominent role in the health of their customers as life expectancy increases and health trends change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy 2030, the number of people aged 60 and older will grow by more than 50 percent, from 900 million in 2015 to 1.4 billion.[[Footnote 3]] Further, noncommunicable diseases\u0026mdash;those more closely linked to lifestyle and behavior, such as diabetes, heart disease, and lung cancer\u0026mdash;will account for 71 percent of all annual deaths globally and represent an increasing proportion of mortality risk.[[Footnote 4]] We believe these factors will motivate life and annuities manufacturers to engage customers in the shared-value economics of healthy living to increase policyholder longevity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTechnology will play an important part in this transition. The proliferation of data and connected devices, particularly wearables, will continue to make it easier for life insurance companies to play an active role in shaping customer health\u0026mdash;to everyone\u0026rsquo;s benefit. Armed with this information, life insurance companies can provide well-timed, personalized reminders or notifications around diet, disease management, doctor appointments, local health resources, and physical activity. Customers are increasingly willing to share their data in exchange for personalization; \u003cspan\u003etoday, six in ten consumers globally are comfortable sharing personal details with their insurer in exchange for lower premiums\u003c/span\u003e.[[Footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis trend has accelerated during the pandemic. Evidence shows that a higher proportion of consumers are willing to share data collected on their watches related to heart rate. In recent months, life insurance companies have relied on more detailed questions and medical records instead of in-person physical exams, which have not been possible with physical distancing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eShared-value life insurance products, such as Vitality, are in the vanguard. Developed by Discovery Group in South Africa, Vitality pioneered the model of shared-value economics in its product design and pricing, leading to the creation of an engaged wellness ecosystem. Now in 22 markets, the program has seen a 35 percent reduction in mortality among highly engaged members and a 15 percent lower policy-lapse rate.[[Footnote 6]] In addition, some Japanese life insurance companies are migrating to a \u0026ldquo;pay as you live\u0026rdquo; premium schedule with dynamic pricing. For example, customers who exhibit regular healthy behaviors, such as exercising and attending doctor checkups, are rewarded with lower premiums. In the future, we expect to see life insurance transition from the traditional \u0026ldquo;assess and service\u0026rdquo; model and shift toward \u0026ldquo;prescribe and prevent\u0026rdquo; (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eContinuous underwriting. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eThe evolution toward continuous underwriting, made possible by increased data and device connectivity, will present further opportunity for personalization. Currently, mortality underwriting suffers from two primary data gaps. First, it is constrained to a single moment in time\u0026mdash;the initial sale. The only data available at that point are past morbidity and behavioral data on the customer. Second, it fails to account for a customer\u0026rsquo;s lifestyle changes, which are significantly more controllable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe envision underwriting evolving in four phases that will increase personalization and customer engagement (Exhibit 6). Currently, insurers focus on automating the underwriting process to improve efficiency gains and reduce inconsistencies (phase 1). Some insurers have advanced to accelerated underwriting, for which applications are submitted digitally (phase 2). Doing so dramatically reduces the need for invasive fluid and paramedical exams and results in near auto-issuance for the majority of policies. Insurers will then graduate to microsegmentation and personalization, for which individualized offers are generated using comprehensive internal and external data sets with enhanced accuracy (phase 3). Finally, winning companies will provide continuous \u0026ldquo;one-touch\u0026rdquo; underwriting, with dynamic adjustment based on customer behavior and suggested personalized actions to significantly drive healthier behavior (phase 4). Together, this four-phase evolution flips the underwriting approach on its head, with environment, health, and lifestyle becoming primary inputs and medical data providing only one part of the picture (Exhibit 7).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n[[Exhibit 7]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ePersonalized, omnichannel customer journeys. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eCOVID-19 has accelerated many of the digital and omnichannel elements that were in their early stages. According to our research, more than 90 percent of new business in China historically has been generated through face-to-face interactions. Since the onset of the pandemic, insurance companies have been forced to adopt digital-hybrid solutions by incorporating robo-advisors, video conferencing, and web chats. Moreover, a recent McKinsey survey of European consumers found that 54 percent of customers now prefer direct or digital channels, up from 38 percent before the crisis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrontline professionals will continue to play a critical role in reaching customers, so insurers must embrace the integration of physical and digital channels once the crisis subsides. Life insurance companies can direct leads to the channel or agent that best serves each customer\u0026rsquo;s needs. Further, agents will be armed with advanced analytics on their customer base as well as centrally provided digital leads. Throughout the customer life cycle, life insurance companies will engage in multichannel, personalized customer interactions to promote cross-selling (by identifying the most likely \u0026ldquo;next product to buy\u0026rdquo;) and proactively reach out to customers who are likely to lapse. Such interactions have the ability to reduce customer acquisition costs by up to 50 percent, generate 5 to 10 percent of new premiums, and reduce customer churn by up to 30 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUpgrading agent capabilities to more effectively use digital tools will be critical to the pending distribution shift. Indeed, a recent McKinsey survey found that \u0026ldquo;generating leads\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;building initial client relationships remotely\u0026rdquo; were the two biggest challenges faced by agents. At the same time, these agents were spending disproportionately more time on customer service and administration than before. Life insurance companies will have to significantly invest in digital infrastructure and place analytics at the core of distribution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDevelop flexible product solutions suitable for a challenging regulatory and interest-rate environment\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInterest rates have been globally depressed for a decade\u0026mdash;and even longer for some economies, such as Germany and Japan. Interest-rate pressure has increased further due to COVID-19, with few signs of abating. At the same time, changing regulations have limited traditional methods of doing business. The most successful life insurers will redouble their focus on innovation and flexibility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eA paradigm shift of the guaranteed product. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eOver the past five to seven years, some countries (such as France, Germany, the Netherlands, and Switzerland) saw new government bonds issued at negative yields. Meanwhile, others (such as the United States and Japan) continue to combat near zero interest rates. Indeed, according to the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority, more than half of European life policies guarantee an investment return to policyholders that exceeds the yield on the local ten-year government bond.[[Footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew capital regulations accompanied the globally depressed rates. For example, the introduction of Solvency II in 2016 in the European Union increased capital requirements for traditional life and annuity products, putting further pressure on profitability. Consumers will continue to seek out guaranteed returns, which means many insurers will face challenges in offering guarantees in a capital-efficient, profitable manner. Collectively, traditional long-term, fixed-rate guaranteed products will undergo a paradigm shift in structure, from being rooted in guaranteed returns to offering upside potential with guaranteed downside protection.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral life insurance companies have already begun moving their portfolios toward a wide variety of capital-markets products, specifically hybrids and unit-linked products, that are more capital efficient and perform well in a low-rate environment. From 2015 to 2019, unit-linked premiums rose $76 billion globally, with European life insurance companies accounting for two-thirds of global growth (Exhibit 8). Such products may offer customers upside potential coupled with downside protection (as high as 100 percent). That said, capital preservation is not free; whether in commissions, expense ratios, or yield, customers pay for it.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 8]]\n\u003cp\u003eRegardless of interest-rate movement, previous fixed-rate guarantees, coupled with new regulations and customer education around alternatives, will likely keep life insurance companies focused on capital-light products in the decade ahead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eTailor new solutions for different life stages.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e In the coming decade, the industry will see the emergence of new types of coverage, as well as increasing flexibility in product coverage and payment. Household debt is still more than 100 percent of net disposable income in most OECD countries,[[Footnote 8]] divorce rates continue to rise, and job insecurity, spurred by technological advancements, can create uncertainty for consumers. Indeed, despite a decade of global economic growth, nearly 50 percent of consumers are somewhat or very concerned about job loss for themselves or \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/mckinsey-2020-global-consumer-sentiment-survey-a-tale-of-two-segments\"\u003ea member of their household\u003c/a\u003e. New products that help allay those concerns, as well as increase coverage and premium flexibility, will likely prove increasingly popular with consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFlexible offerings, which allow the consumer to adjust coverage throughout the life of the policy, have been met with favor in Japan. For example, a leading Japanese insurer offers medical, asset accumulation, and protection against dread disease and mortality wrapped into a single product, enabling the customer to add or reduce coverage as their circumstances change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eValue-added services and nonmonetary benefits. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eOver the next decade, product innovation will likely expand to adjacent services. Life insurance companies, which are competing with not only their peers but also industry alternatives such as pure wealth and asset managers, will increasingly seek to differentiate themselves through value-added services and nonmonetary benefits, particularly as life and health coverage continue to converge.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn Asia and Europe, life insurance companies are already offering administrative support for medical visits,\nhealth management, and telemedicine. Going forward, these companies could also partner with ridesharing companies and hotels to provide transportation to doctor visits or accommodations for loved ones in times of need.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNonmonetary benefits can also address the risk needs of policyholders. For customers concerned with the cost of living in retirement, life insurance companies in Asia and the United Kingdom are replacing financial payouts with guaranteed placement in senior living communities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSuch services give insurers access to fee-based earnings, an alternative revenue stream that could be rewarded by investors. At the same time, fee-based earnings introduce more complexity vis-\u003cspan\u003e\u0026agrave;\u003c/span\u003e-vis sales and after-sales support. Ultimately, earnings potential will be shaped by not only customer demand but also companies\u0026rsquo; abilities to upskill distribution talent and develop unique economic solutions for distributors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eReinvent skills and capabilities\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe path to growth in the next decade will require new talent and bolder strategies. Life insurers must respond by capturing more value from existing assets and pursuing targeted M\u0026amp;A.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eA radically different workforce, underpinned by skills of the future.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e By 2030, 44 percent of insurance work activities have the potential to be automated (Exhibit 9). Roles that focus on repetitive work and manual processes will cease to exist in their present form, while technology and digitally savvy workers will increase in value. Emotional, interpersonal, and social skills will also become more critical, especially for customer-facing agents who can help consumers address their changing financial and coverage needs. However, these workforce shifts will not eliminate jobs\u0026mdash;our research indicates net new jobs will be created due to advances in automation\u0026mdash;but instead change the nature of the work. The COVID-19 pandemic has only accelerated such trends.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 9]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn the war for digital talent, life insurance companies are at a disadvantage. The financial-services industry trails other sectors in volume of digital and tech talent. In fact, 80 percent of millennials say they have limited knowledge of the insurance industry,[[Footnote 9]] a troubling sign for an industry in which 25 percent of employees believe themselves to be within \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-work/the-future-of-work-in-america-people-and-places-today-and-tomorrow\"\u003efive to ten years of retirement\u003c/a\u003e.  However, COVID-19 and recent social unrest present an opportunity for life insurers to reframe their societal purpose, which may help recruit and retain exceptional talent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeventy-five percent of global executives agree that \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-work/retraining-and-reskilling-workers-in-the-age-of-automation\"\u003eupskilling and reskilling employees\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;must account for at least half of their skills gap solution.  Life insurance companies that prioritize those efforts and develop operating models capable of responding to changing demands will distinguish themselves from peers and position themselves at the forefront of \u0026ldquo;future-proofing\u0026rdquo; their workforces.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eSubstantial value from in-force and closed blocks. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eGiven global profitability challenges, insurers can increasingly optimize in-force and closed blocks as a source of value creation. Today, the attention given to in-force management is often not commensurate with its potential. Life insurance companies can enhance in-force value creation by executing across four pillars:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ecommercial effectiveness, including lapse management and cross-selling to policyholders\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003efinancial efficiencies, such as actuarial optimization and reinsurance\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eoperational efficiencies, such as reduced administrative costs\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003etransactions, such as partial or full sales of blocks of business\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies can also extract value from closed blocks, which sometimes have unattractive product economics and operational difficulties or are misaligned with a company\u0026rsquo;s strategy. Yet given their cash flow potential, earnings, and embedded value, closed blocks deserve time, attention, and resources. Some insurers have helped fund investment in a digital transformation or an analytics road map by rationalizing their closed blocks of business.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBy collaborating with actuaries and understanding the implications on the cost model, life insurance companies can often lock in savings and have a onetime release of reserves that is typically in the ten-to-one range (this ratio differs by company). In other words, for every $1 million saved in long-term in-force servicing costs on the closed block, there could be a $10 million onetime reserve release. Life insurance companies often use these funds to finance the transition of the closed blocks to a target platform, invest in digital and analytics, and wide-scale productivity transformations. The reserve can also be used in other ways to reduce the ongoing unit costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe prevalence of closed-block specialists will also spark increased sales by insurance companies beyond\nUS and UK markets, where activity has been high. Specialists, whose scale facilitates lower costs per policy, have proven themselves to be effective operators. Moreover, closed-block sales can provide life insurance companies with immediate access to capital, derisked balance sheets, and a reduction in operational costs, such as legacy IT systems. But life insurance companies must remain open to exploring sales, and they can limit the risk of undervaluing their blocks by keeping an eye on the cost base, considering improvements, and structuring partnerships with potential buyers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003ePrecision M\u0026amp;A for expansion and capability building.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Global M\u0026amp;A remained steady in the 2010s. The Americas accounted for 49 percent of deal volume by the end of the decade, followed by Europe at 32 percent.[[Footnote 10]] Effective M\u0026amp;A\u0026mdash;specifically as a vehicle for market expansion, capability building, and divesting noncore businesses\u0026mdash;can continue to be a core strategy for successful life insurance companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGrowth within existing markets will be challenging; life insurance companies can use acquisitions to enter new geographies, adjacencies, and products. Cross-border transactions can provide access to faster-growing developing markets, such as those in Latin America, and emerging markets in Asia. Moreover, the global middle class, projected to include six billion people by 2030,[[Footnote 11]] will increasingly depend on robust wealth- and asset-management solutions, particularly in markets such as China, where the industry is evolving rapidly. Several life insurance companies have already expanded into such asset-management adjacencies, which have natural synergies with the industry\u0026rsquo;s core competencies. Others may find capital-light, fee-based businesses in areas related to other competencies to be more practical. Regardless, given the historically strong correlation between return on equity and price-to-book ratio, such investors reward higher return-on-equity businesses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLife insurance companies can also rely on acquisitions for tech enablement and capability building. The past decade has witnessed the rise of insurtech, which attracted nearly $4 billion of global venture funding in 2018 alone.[[Footnote 12]] Partially fueling the segment\u0026rsquo;s rise are the increasingly popular internal venture-capital funds launched by life insurance companies themselves. Such funds provide access to leading start-ups and serve as a natural \u0026ldquo;buy\u0026rdquo; versus \u0026ldquo;build\u0026rdquo; entry point for leading technologies. Insurtechs can also help companies increase their pace of innovation. The recent crisis has depressed valuations for start-ups, providing insurers an opportunity to acquire capabilities more cost effectively. As a result, life insurance companies can acquire their way to the forefront of disruptive innovation. If a full acquisition is not an option, hiring talent from insurtechs and other start-ups with greater digital and analytics capabilities is another possibility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, \u0026ldquo;shrink to grow\u0026rdquo; will likely prove a popular way for life insurance companies to launch their next growth S-curves. Divestitures of business lines or books of business, an increasingly popular trend at the end of the 2010s, can unlock capital to focus on new opportunities.\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDownload \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial services/our insights/the future of life insurance reimagining the industry for the decade ahead/the-future-of-life-insurance-final.pdf\"\u003eThe future of life insurance: Reimagining the industry for the decade ahead\u003c/a\u003e, \u003c/em\u003ethe full report on which this article is based (PDF\u0026ndash;896KB).\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Report"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":true},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-09-29T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Older People Projected to Outnumber Children for First Time in U.S. History,\u0026rdquo;
